body:
> > @bschuchardt @pivotal-jbarrett Are there still concerns with this PR?
> 
> My concern over the threadConnectionMap null checks hasn't been addressed. I've been fighting against the nulling-out of instance variables like this forever. It's always causing NPEs for unsuspecting programmers who don't recognize that this anti-pattern is being used. The instance variable ought to be "final" and some other state should be added and consulted to see if the connection table has been closed.

Hi @bschuchardt , 
I think that the best way is to make this threadConnectionMap final and change this `close()` to iterate over the map, close all connections and clear map. In this way, we don't need these null checks.
Writing it to local map and then execute command on it isn't good as `computeIfAbsent()` can throw NPE as we didn't know if someone deleted it as we are checking our local copy.
Since there is no progress on this PR, I will close it.

The approach suggested by @onichols-pivotal is well-intentioned, but could vastly increase the scope of the work. Briefly:
- Java version numbers appear in two contexts: As system requirements and as strings in examples.
- Use of Java versions in system requirements prompted the current two-part division of the variables into main-version and minimum-update. There are only a few occurrences of these, but the variables ensure that they roll in sync with new releases.
- Java versions in examples are scattered throughout the User Guide. This PR addresses 10 of these, but there are almost certainly more. In addition, you can see from the diffs that there are adjacent lines containing hard-coded Java info ("Java version:   1.0.0 user1 041216 2016-11-12 11:18:37 -0700") that are likely out-of-date. Identifying and variable-izing all such occurrences is way beyond the scope of this JIRA ticket.

My recommendation is to accept @alb3rtobr 's current solution as a good step in the right direction.
@jmelchio For your review

Thanks @davebarnes97!.
Please don't merge this yet, though, I'll do it in due time.

@agingade 
I don't think we should go that far with the null checks. In fact, I don't even think we should check for the nullity of the `QueryConfigurationService` in the first place as it should always be created by default [here](https://github.com/apache/geode/blob/develop/geode-core/src/main/java/org/apache/geode/internal/cache/GemFireCacheImpl.java#L1264-L1276).
In order to have more control about which methods should be allowed during an OQL execution, users must implement the `MethodInvocationAuthorizer` interface and use the configuration options we provide; they should never implement the `QueryConfigurationService` directly as it has nothing to do with the actual authorization, its purpose is to control how the query engine is configured. The `QueryConfigurationService` interface is internal and was never meant to be implemented by users at all. They can dig in the code, find the interface, implement it, and manage themselves to override the default service implementation, sure, but that would require some work and access to the actual file system on which Geode is running to "hack" the default service declaration within the `META-INF/services` directory, in which case we can't do nothing about it either.
I'm happy to discuss more about this, I see the following options moving forward:

- Leave things as they are, checking only the nullity of the `QueryConfigurationService` itself to make sure users don't put themselves into a bad situation by manually messing around with the classpath.
- Revert my [last commit on this PR](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/4369/commits/def003221edaefa1faf606bafe70c6bc37c687cc) and leave things as they originally were, that is, don't check for the nullity of `QueryConfigurationService` nor for `QueryConfigurationService.getMethodInvocationAuthorizer()`. This assumes that our users will never implement `QueryConfigurationService`, which is expected as this interface is internal.
- Make `QueryConfigurationService` an internal service, not externally configurable through the `ServiceLoader` mechanism. This would guarantee that only our implementation is used, and avoid returning `null`.
- A mix of the above 3 options: leave the `QueryConfigurationService` externally configurable through the `ServiceLoader` mechanism but also make it a "special service" in the sense that, [during cache initialization](https://github.com/apache/geode/blob/develop/geode-core/src/main/java/org/apache/geode/internal/cache/GemFireCacheImpl.java#L1264-L1276), we throw an exception whenever either the service instance or the returned `MethodInvocationAuthorizer` by the instance are `null`.

@DonalEvans @BenjaminPerryRoss : I might be missing something here, thoughts?.
`DistributedTestOpenJDK11` latest CI run failed but I believe it is due to a CI infrastructure problem. Previous CI run of that test was successful and I made no big changes after that. Merging.

> `testCompile` already extends `compile`. And why are we moving away from `implementation`?

I have changed `compile` & `testCompile` to `compileOnly` & `testCompileOnly` as suggested by @pivotal-jbarrett . That simplifies the expected pom. I tried to use `testCompileOnly` only but the compilation does not work, so both dependencies are needed.
Im closing this PR, I want to investigate this issue more in detail

~~Build works locally for me, could it be a problem of CI infrastructure?~~

I was wrong, I have the same error in `resolveDependencies`

@alb3rtobr There is something funny in how `compileOnly` dependencies get resolved when iterating through dependencies on a task. The same issue pops up on the `geode-assembly:docs` task. @rhoughton-pivot is a Gradle genius so I am sure he will have a 1 liner fix.

@alb3rtobr
in geode-core add:
```
testCompileOnly(platform(project(':boms:geode-all-bom')))
```
and in geode-memcachd add:
```
compileOnly(platform(project(':boms:geode-all-bom')))
```

I have something like this:
```
===================================================================
--- geode-memcached/build.gradle	(revision 518f92650190f52dd3b697004d8d95e38d2f4ff9)
+++ geode-memcached/build.gradle	(date 1574872144345)
@@ -20,11 +20,13 @@
 apply from: "${project.projectDir}/../gradle/publish-java.gradle"
 
 dependencies {
+  compileOnly(platform(project(':boms:geode-all-bom')))
+  compileOnly('com.github.stephenc.findbugs:findbugs-annotations')
+
   implementation(platform(project(':boms:geode-all-bom')))
   implementation(project(':geode-core'))
   implementation(project(':geode-logging'))
   implementation('org.apache.logging.log4j:log4j-api')
-  implementation('com.github.stephenc.findbugs:findbugs-annotations')
 
   testImplementation('org.mockito:mockito-core')
   testImplementation(project(':geode-junit'))
===================================================================
--- geode-assembly/build.gradle	(revision 518f92650190f52dd3b697004d8d95e38d2f4ff9)
+++ geode-assembly/build.gradle	(date 1574868433905)
@@ -360,7 +360,6 @@
             it.contains('mx4j') ||
 
             // misc jars, these should be removed from the lib dir
-            it.contains('findbugs-annotations') ||
             it.contains('geode-dependencies') ||
             it.contains('geode-jca') ||
             it.contains('geode-web') ||
===================================================================
--- geode-core/build.gradle	(revision 518f92650190f52dd3b697004d8d95e38d2f4ff9)
+++ geode-core/build.gradle	(date 1574872132480)
@@ -149,6 +149,7 @@
   //These bom dependencies are used to constrain the versions of the dependencies listed below
   api(platform(project(':boms:geode-all-bom')))
   compileOnly(platform(project(':boms:geode-all-bom')))
+  testCompileOnly(platform(project(':boms:geode-all-bom')))
   // As plugin configurations that do not extend from compile,
   // we must explicitly impose version constraints on these configurations.
   antlr platform(project(':boms:geode-all-bom'))
@@ -174,7 +175,8 @@
   compileOnly files("${System.getProperty('java.home')}/../lib/tools.jar")
 
   //Find bugs is used in multiple places in the code to suppress findbugs warnings
-  implementation('com.github.stephenc.findbugs:findbugs-annotations')
+  compileOnly('com.github.stephenc.findbugs:findbugs-annotations')
+  testCompileOnly('com.github.stephenc.findbugs:findbugs-annotations')
 
   //Jgroups is a core component of our membership system.
   implementation('org.jgroups:jgroups')
```

https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/4364

In my last test, I finally got `resolveDependencies` working by leaving the dependencies as:

`compileOnly('com.github.stephenc.findbugs:findbugs-annotations')
testCompile('com.github.stephenc.findbugs:findbugs-annotations')`

And the generated pom does not have the findbugs-annotations dependency. I will test you code, I prefer to use `testCompileOnly`. Thanks!

Thanks for reviewing @jhuynh1 
Please find my answers below, inline for an easier follow-up.

> I thought clearing the local cq cache was needed if we updated the cq context with the new authorizer.

The CQ will always pick up the latest configured authorizer, no matter wether the `forceUpdate` flag is set as `true` or `false`, this logic is part of the `reset` method invoked by CQs during the execution. See [`CqServiceImpl.evaluateQuery`](https://github.com/apache/geode/blob/develop/geode-cq/src/main/java/org/apache/geode/cache/query/cq/internal/CqServiceImpl.java#L1604-L1607) and [`ExecutionContext.reset`](https://github.com/apache/geode/blob/develop/geode-core/src/main/java/org/apache/geode/cache/query/internal/ExecutionContext.java#L587-L591).

> If they have the old authorizer, why do we need to clear the cache?

If we don't clear the cache, the CQ won't be evaluated for those keys that are part of the cache, which can result in invoking `onEvent` instead of `onError` for the associated `CqListener`.

---

As an example, let's say the user has the CQ  `SELECT * from /testRegion object WHERE object.getId() > -1` running in the cluster, the configured `MethodInvocationAuthorizer` allows `getId` to be invoked. Some time passes and the CQ internal cache builds up to improve performance.
At that point the user decides to install a new `MethodInvocationAuthorizer` that doesn't allow `getId`. If we don't invalidate the internal CQ cache, the engine will invoke `onError` for events **that are not part of the internal cache** (the CQ will be executed) and `onEvent` for those events that **that are part of the internal cache** (the CQ won't be executed), which is not consistent.
Long story short, by invalidating the internal cache we make sure the CQ will be re-executed for every event  no matter what, and the execution itself will result in error if the newly configured authorizer doesn't allow the execution of methods present in the CQ expression.
Hope it makes sense now, please let me know your thoughts.
Cheers.
This initial PR contains two commits. The first should essentially just contain file moves. The second contains code changes that would be more relevant for reviewing.
@jmelchio For your review

My review was on an older change-set... I would have -1 this, for the `retry<=2` for create_instance jobs. The roulette nature of the work means that we can fail twice 1/4 times when a failure happens the first time.
If we start seeing `create_instance` failures, we'll have to re-increase that attempts number.

I have no problem increasing it if we see a case where more retries could arguably make a difference.  Unfortunately with 10 we only saw the cases where retries didn't help.  Other pipelines I've looked at tend to stick with 2-3 retries.  Any issue that persists after 2-3 tries is probably worth bubbling up to our attention.

if we don't define the synonyms inside IndexType class, then I agree with you. If the IndexType is aware of the synonyms, then it's the responsibility of the class itself to provide a translation.

> The mapping between the new `IndexType` enum and the old names is needed only by the converter. I think it's a mistake to put that mapping into `IndexType`, and to make the mapping visible via a method (`valueOfSynonym()`). Putting that method into `IndexType` makes the mapping part of the public API.

This is only solution with updated config parameter. Start working on Jens proposal.

Idea is that ssl-server-name-extension will contain generic string value which will be passed as Server Name extension in Client Hello message.  Could you clarify your idea. What will be content of ssl-parameter-extension parameter?

If the user wishes to manipulate `SSLParameter`s (say in order to add their own SNI value) they would need to implement an interface something like:
```
public interface SSLParameterExtension {
  SSLParameter modify(SSLParameter, SSLConfig);
}
```
On starting Geode, they would provide the following parameter:
```
ssl-parameter-extension=com.example.ssl.MySSLParams.class
```
When the `SSLConfig` class is created it would also create (and hold a reference to) an instance of this class. At the point where SSLParameters need to be adjusted, this class' `modify` method could be called in order to perform whatever changes the user wants.

Depending on your particular use case you may need to also have the interface provide an `init()` method with whatever parameters are necessary for `modify` to do what you want - perhaps `Cache` or `DistributionConfig` - something fairly general so that additional use cases would likely also be satisfied in the future.

another good test to add is to create a region in one group, and try to create index on that region in another group.

Finally this is the only way I found to implement a consistent behavior:

The problem is that if the output of `list gateways --senders --receivers` is the same than `list gateways`, that means that `specifiedDefaultValue` and `unspecifiedDefaultValue` have to be `true` for both parameters. But in that case, when executing `list gateways --senders` or `list gateways --receivers` both parameters will be `true`.

So with the last commit:
* `list gateways --senders --receivers` and `list gateways --senders=true --receivers=true` will return error
* `list gateways --senders=false --receivers=false` and any combination using "one true and one false" will be like running `list gateways`.
* `list gateways --senders` and `list gateways --senders=true` will show only senders.
* `list gateways --receivers` and `list gateways --receivers=true` will show only receivers.
